title: ‘Half an Olive Branch’ Fails to Pacify Hong Kong Protesters
text:
HONG KONG—For three months, protests here have been sustained by two forces: the peaceful marchers, and the more radical activists who are willing to confront authorities on the front lines. The city’s leader aimed to sow divisions between the two camps in explaining her first conciliatory moves in months to try to quell social unrest.

That may not prove so easy in a city where polls show many people had turned against the government and police during the unrest, and anger is still running high.

On Thursday, explaining why she withdrew an extradition bill that kick-started a summer of dissent in the city, Chief Executive Carrie Lam said “society” would like “peaceful demonstrators not to provide a legitimate basis for the really violent protesters.”

Her refusal to authorize an independent inquiry into how police have handled the protests, the opposition camp says, means neither of the opposition forces will be placated.

“If you want to talk about violence, we need to deal with police brutality first,” said Claudia Mo, convener of the pro-democracy bloc of legislators. “If they refuse to acknowledge or deal with police actions, there is very little we can do to proceed.”

Prominent figures from the pro-democracy movement say those legislators are the most logical bridge between the protesters and the government. Ms. Mo said the elected group of lawmakers previously asked several times for meetings with Mrs. Lam in the past few months and were told it wasn’t the right time, according to a number of lawmakers from the camp.

Now that Mrs. Lam has said she is seeking dialogue, Ms. Mo will consult with allies on how best to proceed. Ms. Mo said it was unconscionable that the pan-democratic bloc wasn’t invited to Government House to hear about Mrs. Lam’s decision on Wednesday, even though dozens of pro-Beijing legislators were in attendance.

What started off as a demonstration against a controversial extradition bill has become a series of massive protests with broad political demands. Here is why so many Hong Kongers keep taking to the streets in a leaderless movement and whether their goals can be achieved. Photo: Thomas Peter/Reuters

On Thursday, Mrs. Lam was at pains to assert her authority, rather than Beijing’s, in dealing with the crisis. The extradition bill—which would have allowed people to be sent to China for trial—was initiated, introduced and now withdrawn by her government, she said. She added that Beijing has backed her administration throughout the process.

China’s central government and state media have stayed relatively muted on Mrs. Lam’s decision to formally pull the bill and initiate an independent review of Hong Kong’s political, economic and social climate. As of Thursday evening, neither Beijing’s Hong Kong and Macau Affairs Office nor the central-government liaison office in the territory had issued any public comment on Mrs. Lam’s four-point plan for easing social tensions.

Asked at a routine briefing Thursday whether Beijing had forced or advised Mrs. Lam to withdraw the bill, Chinese Foreign Ministry spokesman Geng Shuang told reporters that the matter wasn’t a diplomatic issue and referred the question to the “relevant authority.” The ministry omitted the question and Mr. Geng’s response from its official transcript of the briefing.

Mr. Geng also warned U.S. politicians to stop meddling in Hong Kong’s affairs, after Sen. Marco Rubio (R., Fla.) said Wednesday that the withdrawal was a “welcome but insufficient step after the government’s violent response to the Hong Kong people’s desire to protect their democratic freedoms.”

State broadcaster China Central Television hasn’t referred to Mrs. Lam’s plan in its evening newscast. On Wednesday evening, the government-run Xinhua News Agency ran a terse two-paragraph story on Mrs. Lam’s plan, including the bill’s withdrawal. The Communist Party’s official newspaper, the People’s Daily, published an identical report on the fourth page of its Thursday edition.

In contrast, when Mrs. Lam suspended the bill in mid-June, Chinese officials and state media weighed in within hours. Representatives of the Hong Kong and Macau Affairs Office and the liaison office expressed support for Mrs. Lam and her decision. CCTV reported on the suspension in its evening newscast on the same day, while the People’s Daily ran a commentary the next day backing Mrs. Lam and her government.

Chinese censors have also appeared to curb social-media discussions of the withdrawal of the extradition bill. On the Weibo microblogging service, user comments on some state-media posts regarding Mrs. Lam’s announcement were rendered unviewable.

“We’re getting to life-and-death situations in Hong Kong,” said Holden Chow, a lawmaker and vice chairman of the city’s largest pro-Beijing party. Mr. Chow said he would like to see peace restored as soon as possible and urged pan-democratic legislators to condemn violence of any kind.

Hong Kong’s chief executive, Carrie Lam, said ‘society’ would like ‘peaceful demonstrators not to provide a legitimate basis for the really violent protesters.’ Photo: jeon heon-kyun/epa/Shutterstock

China is applying a well-worn Communist Party playbook for tackling public unrest, said Steve Tsang, director of the SOAS China Institute in London.

The goal is to isolate “the activist protesters who resort to violence from the vast majority who prefer to demonstrate peacefully, and make the activist protesters look unreasonable,” said Mr. Tsang. “Which then makes it appear justifiable for the authorities to resort to a higher level of repression that targets this group.”

Bonnie Leung, vice convener of the organizers of the summer’s biggest marches, said authorities were trying to drive a wedge in the movement. “What we need is an olive branch, and what we’re seeing is half an olive branch,” she said, emphasizing the need for an independent inquiry into how police have handled the protests.

Ms. Leung said her group, the Civil Human Rights Front, is planning more protests, tentatively on Sept. 15 and on Oct. 1, the 70th anniversary of the founding of Communist China, though the march would focus on the Hong Kong movement.

“We think all protesters—the peaceful and the brave—are all fighting for the same thing,” she said. “These tactics to divide us won’t work, and we will continue to be united and join together.”

—Jeremy Page in Beijing contributed to this article.

Write to Natasha Khan at natasha.khan@wsj.com and Chun Han Wong at chunhan.wong@wsj.com
description: For three months, Hong Kong protests have been sustained by two forces: the peaceful marchers, and the more radical activists. Now, the city’s leader has aimed to sow divisions between the two camps.
